children.subject:
I actually find (some) of  the material interesting. I just don't like the sheer amount of homework, the  difficulty, and the general organization of the class. Subjects aren't very related so I feel like I'm not actually building up knowledge in anything, just trying to figure out random, unrelated puzzles. I have virtually no time to actually learn/understand the material between homework and studying for the exams. I guess overall it just seems like the class is more intended to weed kids out of the major than prepare students and give them the skills they need to succeed in other computer science courses. I found the section about the SMA really interesting, and graphs kind of interesting, but the actual problems on homework/exams  I just find frustrating since they tend to be so unlike anything we see/learn.

So I guess more so the difficulty of the material, and just the overall structure of the class.

I'm a bit confused though about your comment about having no time to learn/understand the material. If you're doing the homework and studying for the exams, presumably in that time you're learning the material. If you're not, then I would suggest you try to learn the material first, which should more than compensate by decreasing the amount of time you spend on homework and studying for exams.

But otherwise, I'm going to comment specifically on your last question in your OP, about comparing upper divs to CS70.

Obviously, perceived workload varies greatly both by person and by course. I would say that there are several upper-divs with similar workload (i.e. the ones that have a reputation for being harder), and some others with much less .

The fact that subjects aren't very related is partially a result of CS70 being an intro-level lower-div, and needing to cover a number of topics to prepare students for upper-divs, and thus not meant to be a specialized course. (Although the second half of the course, the probability section, is much more cohesive.)

But depending on the upper-div, many courses are like this, while many others are not. For example, I know that 170 and 188 (the other two courses I've TA'd for) are also subject to similar comments. For 188, there have been ineffective attempts by the professors in prior semesters to try to build a theme / connect the topics together, but ultimately, as an intro course to the broad field of AI (like 170 is for algorithms and CS theory). that class also is unable to spend much time in any particular one area. Ultimately, I consider both 170 and 188 as more grab-bag-like courses than 70 is. (170 has a reasonable excuse for this: in real life, when you solve a problem and try to design an algortihm, you likely don't know beforehand what a good approach to solve the problem is.)

But there are also other courses (e.g. project-based ones where you build on the same project as the semester progresses) that are more well-connected topic-wise.
What about CS70 do you dislike? Is it the difficulty of the material or the material itself?

following. I have the same feeling and similar situation. I did really good in 61A and other math courses, and doing good so far in 61B, but got 1 std below the average in 70.. I have never done so bad on an exam

That definitely sounds much more enjoyable to me. I think a big part of why I'm having such an issue with the class is because I struggle to see the utility of a lot of things we learn (beyond just building proof writing/problem solving skills). I'm actually really interested in algorithms in general and looked forward to taking 170

Honestly I think that's the bulk of what you learn in the beginning of 70 (proofwriting/problem solving). RSA is useful for security (161), and the graph theory section is useful for quite a few other courses, but I haven't used anything else from the discrete math section.

My advice to you would be to go to OH, form study groups, and just power your way thorough this course: you definitely don't need to love 70 to be a CS major.

The second half of 70 is very different from the first half (discrete math vs probability). Many upper divs are similar to the 61 series (188 like 61b, 162 like 61c), though some of the more theory-based courses are similar to 70.

The most similar is 170. I'm currently taking 170, but I find it much more enjoyable than 70. The course organization is the same, in that there are weekly problem sets that take ~15 hours, and no projects. But the homework questions are mainly algorithm design, which is very important to programming. A lot of them are actually common interview questions, or variations of. You use what you learn about proofwriting from 70 in 170, but other than that, the topics are fairly different.

history.content:
Yes, you can dislike 70 and still love the CS major. I also did exactly average on my first 70 midterm, and one week I went to OH every day to hammer out solutions, then took so long typing it up and forgetting what I'd just proved that I turned it in incomplete. But in the long term, 70 did nothing to dampen my interest in the major.

Like the other commenter, I enjoyed the second half of CS70 a lot more than the first half (counting and probability is cool, and super useful). I've used probability in CS161, CS168, CS169, CS170, CS188, CS189 (yeah, some more than others). And I loved CS170, which teaches you all sorts of neat algorithms and challenges you to apply them in interesting ways and invent your own algorithms.

Don't give up! And go to OH a lot.

children.subject: Once you get into upper division courses, you can start to figure out what subjects you do/don't like. I HATED CS 70 when I took it, but after finishing my lower divs, I found that I actually ended up liking a lot of systems courses like CS 162/186. So yea, it could still be your major. Use the lower div courses to see where most of your interests lie, and choose your upper div courses accordingly.

I absolutely hated CS70. I got a B- and I'm honestly not sure how I did -- literally understood and took away almost no probability from that class and was absolutely disillusioned with majoring in CS after that, thinking another class like that might knock me out entirely. This was also on the heels of 61C so I had just had two not great semesters where the thing I loved (project programming) almost never appeared. Fast forward to 1 year later, I've taken or am taking CS188 (loved it -- and learned way more probability from it than I did from CS70), CS186 (liked it), CS161 (liking it), and CS100 (liking it).

Sure, if I take CS170 (which I plan not to do) I might find myself hating CS again but that's why such a breadth of CS courses exist :) 

Persevere! Your CS70 semester might be one of the worst you've ever had (it definitely was my second worse in college) but at the end of it try your best not to feel disillusioned.

So far, CS 70 has been the hardest course I have taken, and I've taken a lot of other CS courses to compare to (61C, 170, 188, and 189, etc..) In fact, my TA from 70 said that this should probably be a uperdiv not a lowerdiv. Part of the problem is that this class is the final step for many for declaring CS, so has a large competitive aspect to it. I personally found 170 to be on the order of magnitudes easier than 70, but that may be because I did a lot of algorithmic coding competitions before I took 170. Even if you end up disliking 70, do give 170 a shot. Almost every CS major ends up taking this course, and many of my friends were in the course at the same time, something I can't say about other courses like 189.

history.content:
I've always considered myself decent at math (A in Math 1A, A+ in Math 1B, and B+ in Math 54), but CS70 is absolutely killing me. I'm doing okay-ish (got almost exactly the average on the first midterm), but I've never found a class so unenjoyable and it's making me question if this major is right for me. I've really loved the 61 series so far (they've probably been my favorite classes at Cal), so I'm really unsure what to do.

Which of these classes are more similar to upper div classes? I'm not sure if I could take many more classes similar to CS70, I find it overwhelming to the point of being seriously detrimental to the point of seriously affecting my general mood/emotions. 

What can I do to enjoy the class more? If I dislike 70 this much will I hate upper division classes as well?
history.subject: Loved 61A, really enjoying 61B, but hate CS70 - Is the major right for me?
